In particular, [1] showed IA achieves the maximum degrees of freedom of the interference channel with time or frequency selectivity, though the degree of freedom frontier for constant channels is still unknown except with 3 users where it coincides with the time or frequency selective case.

Cadambe and Jafar [1] showed that interference alignment achieves the maximum degrees of freedom in the K-user MIMO relay channel with frequency or time selectivity, at the same time proving (surprisingly) that the number of spatial degrees of freedom scales linearly with number of users in the interference channel.
For this proof, [1] codes an infinite block of symbols over an infinite number of independent frequency or time dimensions.
In this case, the maximum achievable spatial degrees of freedom are unknown [4], except for the 3-user case [1], where frequency or time selectivity do not increase the spatial degrees of freedom.
For instance, in the 3-user case it is known that two antennas per user are required to achieve one degree of freedom per user [1].

context.text: The tracking algorithm presented in this paper is based on the correlation of the target intensity feature between consecutive frames through the computation of the so-called intensity variation function (IVF) [2].
The complexity of the algorithm proposed in [2] is strictly related to the core phase aimed at searching the target within a portion of the image, called the subframe.

The key contribution of this paper is a novel strategy for performing the search into the subframe by means of a genetic algorithm (GA); the proposed solution is able to estimate the target coordinates in the image plane, reducing the computational cost with respect to [2], without affecting the tracking robustness.

Several tests, performed on real FLIR video sequences taken from a small unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), as well as on a subset of the object tracking and classification in and beyond the visible spectrum (OTCBVS) data set [20], were used to compare the proposed GA-based approach with the original tracking method presented in [2]; experimental tests showed how the application of the evolutionary process can significantly reduce the processing time of the target search phase.
A feasible (and more efficient) approach for automatic tracking of single and multiple targets has been proposed in [2].

Other related nonparametric techniques for multidimensional signal processing have emerged in recent years as well. in particular, the concept of normalized convolution [17], and the introduction of support vector machines [18] are notable examples. in the present work, the steering techniques in [15] are extended to 3-D where, as we will demonstrate, we can perform high fidelity space-time upscaling and super-resolution.
